--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, cgreen@d... wrote:

> 
> Certainly if you did a prune phase upon every single improvement I 
can imagine 
> this would be very inefficient. I remember now that this is why I 
suggested 
> pruning only after a period of stagnation... the theory being that 
you just 
> leave the neutral structure and continue searching in the higher 
space while it 
> is still working. If you then reach a point of stagnation *then* 
prune your way 
> back to the lower search space - which could be quite a bit lower 
for the first 
> prune.
> 
> Of course if you did this and still stagnated then you wouldn't 
want to trigger 
> off another prune phase, there would be no point. So perhaps if we 
set a flag 
> that tells us that pruning is an option, and which gets set to 
true whenever an 
> improvement is found. So when stagnation does occur we check the 
flag first 
> before deciding to prune.
> 

Here's an interesting idea:  Do your pruning idea on a per-species 
basis instead of on the whole population.  In other words, see if a 
species has improved, and then if the species is stagnant, set a 
flag inside the species saying mutations for the while should be 
pruning mutations.  That way, different species can be in different 
phases out of phase with each other.

This kind of per-species analysis is possible in NEAT 
implementations that are like mine since I keep keep track of 
species continuity throughout the run.  In other words, my NEAT 
implementation knows how long it's been since the last improvement 
of every species.  If you do speciation like I do, this is possible.

ken
